attributes.title: Identifying Disparities in Hospice Access for Patients with Complex or Costly Illnesses

q1.value: Identifying Disparities in Hospice Access for Patients with Complex or Costly Illnesses

q2.value: Elizabeth Trandel, Megan Bannon, Tamar Krishnamurti, Dio Kavalieratos

q3.value: Hospice provides medical care and psychosocial support to patients with life-limiting illnesses who are expected to live less than six months. Hospice reimbursement is based on a per diem rate for each patient-day of hospice care, regardless of patient diagnosis.  Given this financial structure, many hospice agencies have enrollment policies that restrict access to care for patients with expensive treatments. Anecdotal evidence suggests that patients with complex or costly diseases, such as cystic fibrosis and heart failure, have difficulty gaining access to hospice care. The goal of this study is to determine whether medication cost, complexity of disease, or disease rarity are associated with hospice willingness to accept patients.

q4.value:
1. Hospices are more likely to admit “low-cost” than “high-cost” patients with heart failure and cystic fibrosis. 
2. Hospices are more likely to admit “low-cost, low-complexity” than “low-cost, high-complexity” patients with heart failure and cystic fibrosis.
3. Hospices are less likely to admit a "low-cost, low-complexity" cystic fibrosis patient than a "low-cost, low-complexity" heart failure patient.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is an online vignette-based survey study distributed through Qualtrics, an online survey platform. This survey has a 2x3 format, in which each respondent will randomly receive one of six hypothetical patient vignettes:
1. “High-cost, high-complexity” heart failure patient: Continuous infusion of inotrope + low-cost oral medications (total weekly medication cost: $795.18).
2. “Low-cost, high-complexity” heart failure patient: Continuous infusion of inotrope + low-cost oral medications; patient has funds from online donation page to pay for meds (total weekly medication cost: $0).
3. “Low-cost, low-complexity” heart failure patient: Low-cost oral medications (total weekly medication cost: $157.78).
4. “High-cost, high-complexity” cystic fibrosis patient: Expensive combination of medications necessary for symptom relief (total weekly medication cost: $1503.25 or $3751.58, alternating monthly).
5. “Low-cost, high-complexity” cystic fibrosis patient: Expensive combination of medications necessary for symptom relief; funds from online donation page to pay for meds total weekly medication cost: $0).
6. “Low-cost, low-complexity” cystic fibrosis patient: Willing to stop all medications except supplemental oxygen therapy (total weekly medication cost: $56).

Respondents are asked to rate the likelihood that they would admit the patient to their hospice on a scale of 0-100%. If the respondent chooses a likelihood less than 100%, he or she is then asked to choose among the following barriers that make them hesitant to admit the patient: treatment cost, diagnosis and familiarity with the disease process, lack of hospice resources and personnel to support the patient’s needs, ethical reasons, or “other.” The respondent is asked to provide a free-response explanation for why each barrier they indicated makes them hesitant to admit the patient.  We are also collecting both respondent demographic information (age, race, ethnicity, and role in hospice organization) and hospice characteristics (size, profit status, location, and hospice affiliations with academic institutions).

q9.value: We are using block randomization in this study to ensure balance between the six vignettes.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: We did a one-time data pull to ensure that our block randomization scheme was working properly (i.e. that we had balance between the vignettes).

question.value: This study is using convenience sampling through online recruiting methods. The survey is being distributed through organization listservs, weekly newsletters, message boards, and Twitter posts to reach members of the following national hospice organizations: the American Academy of Hospice and Palliative Medicine, the National Hospice and Palliative Care Organization, and the Hospice and Palliative Nurses Association. Respondents are assigned to one of the six hypothetical patient vignettes through block randomization. Respondents must be involved in hospice admissions decisions (i.e. medical director, nurse administrator, intake coordinator, etc.). At the end of the survey, participants are given the option to be chosen at random for one of four $50 gift cards.

q13.value: We are using a convenience sample frame. Given that this is an exploratory study, we have no prior information on which to base a sample size requirement.

q14.value: This is an exploratory study with no prior data to calculate a minimally important clinical difference and thus a sample size. Therefore, we will stop recruitment based on time the survey is open for completion, rather than a sample size target.

q15.value: The survey will be open for a total of 10 weeks. This timeframe was chosen based on time and logistical factors.

question.value: The main outcome variable we will measure is the percent likelihood of admitting the patient to hospice, which respondents will rate on a scale of 0-100%. We will also record the barriers that respondents indicate make them hesitant to admit the patient, along with “free response” explanations.

We plan to conduct pairwise comparisons using T-tests:
1. For both the heart failure and cystic fibrosis patients, we will compare the “high-cost, high-complexity” patient to the “low-cost, high-complexity” patient to determine if cost is a barrier to access to hospice care when the complexity of the patients’ needs is high.
2. For both the heart failure and cystic fibrosis patients, we will compare the “low-cost, high-complexity” patient to the “low-cost, low-complexity” patient to determine if complexity of needs is a barrier to access when medication cost is low.
3. We will compare the “low-cost, low-complexity” heart failure vignette with the “low-cost, low-complexity” cystic fibrosis vignette to determine if disease rarity plays a role in the decision to admit to hospice care.
4. We will compare the heart failure vignettes to the cystic fibrosis vignettes in a pair-wise fashion for each of the three case-types: “high-cost, high-complexity,” “low-cost, high-complexity,” and “low-cost, low-complexity” to determine if there is a similar likelihood of admission to hospice care between them.
5. We will use multivariable regression to control for potential confounding variables.

q21.value: We will use p<0.05 as the threshold for establishing statistical significance of all tests.

q23.value: Subjects who do not complete the question related to the likelihood of admitting the patient into hospice will be excluded from analysis.

q24.value: We expect that respondent and hospice demographic information may influence the likelihood of admitting patients into hospice. Therefore, we will determine if hospice characteristics (size, profit status, location, and hospice affiliations) and respondent information (role in hospice organization) are related to the primary outcome of the likelihood of admitting patients into hospice.

attributes.title: Drop-out and transfer-out intentions.  The role of academic and social integration.

q1.value: Drop-out and transfer-out intentions. The role of academic and social integration

q2.value: Efim Nemtcan, Rannveig Grøm Sæle, Thor Gamst-Klaussen, Frode Svartdal

q3.value: Obtaining a higher education diploma has become an essential prerequisite for economic and social mobility, success, and well-being. However, attrition across European universities is high (Vossensteyn et al., 2015). According to Aamodt and Hovdhaugen (2011), attrition rates among investigated cohorts of Norwegian students are stable and vary around 20%. The issue represents a social (e.g., ineffective use of governmental funding, financial loss for state universities) as well as individual loss (e.g., time spent unemployed). Attrition is a multifaceted phenomenon and can vary depending on the reasons and observed consequences of the behavior, e.g., drop-out, transfer out, stop-out, opt-out (Hoyt & Winn, 2004). Few studies explicitly investigate differences in factors predicting these types of attrition. To our knowledge, only Hovdhaugen (2009) addressed this issue in the Norwegian context by comparing causes of drop-out and transfer out behaviors among university students. Consequently, a cross-cultural investigation of the phenomenon is required. Further, based on the Student Attrition Model by Bean (1982), and The Student Retention Integrated Model by Cabrera, Nora, and Castaneda (1993), students’ intentions are significant determinants of future behavior. The assumption is in accordance with the Theory of Reasoned Action (Fishbein & Ajzen, 1975) and the Theory of Planned Behavior (Ajzen, 1991). However, not every intention is realized (Bagozzi & Yi, 1989). The solution has been proposed by Gollwitzer (1990) in the Mindset Theory of Action Phases, implementation intentions. The available evidence facilitates validity of the notion (Bagozzi & Yi, 1989; Rise, Thompson, & Verplanken, 2003). In the current study, we aim to investigate if two Tinto’s (1975) most prominent constructs of academic and social integration would show the same pattern of relationship with drop-out and transfer out intentions/implementation intentions. The relationships between these two constructs and attrition intentions has been rarely investigated. Our second aim is to investigate the relationship between procrastination and students’ intentions. To our knowledge, only a single study by Grau and Minguillon (2013) addressed this issue.

q4.value:
See attached file for the graphic representation of hypothesises.

Hypothesis 1:

4.1.	Directional: Better academic and social integration would be related to higher/lower drop-out and transfer out intentions among students (e.g., Bean, 1982; Cabrera et al., 1993; Fishbein & Ajzen, 1975; Gollwitzer, 1990; Tinto, 1975).

4.2.	Directional: Higher academic performance would be related to attrition intentions (e.g., Bean & Metzner, 1985; Pascarella & Terenzini, 1980).

4.3.	Directional: Direct and indirect effect of time-management skills on attrition intentions would be mediated/moderated by students’ self-efficacy (Foerst, Klug, Jöstl, Spiel, & Schober, 2017).

 
o	Directional: Higher time-management skills and self-efficacy would be related to lower attrition intentions via higher academic integration, e.g., indirect effect (Tinto, 1975; Bean & Metzner, 1985).

o	Directional: Higher scores on time-management skills and self-efficacy could also be directly related to lower attrition intentions, e.g., direct effect (Ajzen, 1991; Gollwitzer, 1990; Robbins et al., 2004).

Hypothesis 2:

4.4.	Directional: More reported procrastination would be related to more attrition intentions and the relationship would be mediated/moderated by time-to-degree (Bair & Haworth, 2005; Klingsieck, Grund, Schmid, & Fries, 2013; Muszynski & Akamatsu, 1991; Wadkins, 1999).

4.5.	Directional: The relationship between procrastination and attrition intentions would be mediated/moderated by academic integration (Klingsieck et al., 2013; Tinto, 1975).

4.6.	Directional: The relationship between procrastination and attrition intentions would be mediated/moderated by performance (Klingsieck et al., 2013; Steel, 2007).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Participants are not aware of the concrete study aims. Aims of the study are described in general terms sufficient to make informed decision about participation in the study.

question.value: Correlational study design. Proposed theoretical model(s) will be analyzed with Structural Equation Model (SEM) method.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Potential participant from different Norwegian institutions of higher education (e.g., UiO University of Oslo, UiB University of Bergen, NTNU Norwegian University of Science and Technology, UiT The Arctic University of Norway) will be invited to complete a short questionnaire (8-10 minutes). Students will be recruited through an e-mail (university’s mail addresses), social media (Facebook), and snowballing. 

Data collection has begun in November 2019 and will continue until the end of February (2020). The questionnaire is separated into two parts. The aim of splitting the questionnaire is to increase response rate and statistical power of the study (Galesic & Bosnjak, 2009). The first part is focused on students’ time-management skills, self-efficacy, integration and attrition intentions. Only two questions from Academic Procrastination Scale (APS) index are included. In the second part of the questionnaire, students will be asked to answer seven questions from APS. We aim to obtain a more valid indicator of students’ procrastination. Time-management skills and self-efficacy measures will be reduced to two measures based on CFA results of the first part of the study (e.g., highest loadings). All other measurement scales are similar to those used in the first part. Participants will be invited to participate in the lottery where they could win 1 out of 15 gift cards.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 641 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 700 accounting for attrition rates (10%). Our goal in testing Model 1 (Figure 1) is to obtain .95 power to detect low size (Cohen’s d) of .20 at the standard alpha error level = .05 (8 latent variables and 29 observed variables). We do not expect to obtain equally large sample for our second questionnaire. Thus, we aim to collect responses from at least 500 participants. The sample size is appropriate for obtaining .85 power level to detect low effect (d = .20) at the standard alpha level of .05. Soper’s (2019) a-priori sample size calculator for structural equation models was used to determine required sample size. No previous research that is similar to the current study was indicated. Consequently, our sample size estimation was based on evaluation of effects sizes reported between different sets of variables (e.g., Bean, 1982; Richardson, Abraham, & Bond, 2012; Robbins et al., 2004), time constrains, and feasibility.

question.value:
Time-management skills. The time management subscale from ASSIST inventory will be used to measure study-related skills (Diseth, 2007). The items were chosen based on their internal reliability (Cronbach’s Alpha .72; Diseth, 2001), possible data collection issues, and diversity of our sample (e.g., humanity, medicine, STEM students). Response options ranged from 1 = Totally agree to 5 = Totally disagree. A subset of two items will be used in the second part of the questionnaire based on highest loadings (results of the first questionnaire).

Items (English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey): 
o	I organise my study time carefully to make the best use of it / Jeg organiserer studietiden min nøye for å utnytte den best mulig.
o	I’m pretty good at getting down to work whenever I need to / Jeg er ganske flink å komme i gang med skolearbeidet når jeg trenger.
o	I work steadily through the term or semester, rather than leave it all until the last minute / Jeg jobber heller jevnt gjennom hele semesteret fremfor å la alt vente til siste liten
o	I generally make good use of my time during the day / Stort sett kan jeg bruke tiden godt gjennom arbeidsdagen.

Academic self-efficacy.  The measurement index is borrowed from a Danish study by Herrmann, Bager-Elsborg, and McCune (2017). Scale is based on MSLQ (Motivated Strategies for Learning Questionnaire) by Pintrich et al. (1991). Self-efficacy, as it is used here, refers to the students’ self-appraisal of their ability to master a task and includes judgment about their ability to accomplish a task as well as their confidence in their skills to perform that task (Pintrich et al. 1991). Three items were chosen based on the reported highest loadings (Hermann et al., 2017). Original Cronbach’s alpha (five items) was .83. A subset of two items will be used in the second part of the questionnaire based on highest loadings (results of the first questionnaire).

Items (English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey):: 

o	I am confident that I can acquire the skills necessary to excel within my field of study / Jeg er trygg på at jeg kan tilegne meg ferdighetene som er nødvendige for å utmerke meg innen mitt studiefelt.
o	I believe I will do well in my studies, as long as I make an effort / Jeg har tro på at jeg skal gjøre det bra i studiet, så lenge jeg gjør en innsats.
o	I expect to do well in my studies / Jeg forventer at jeg skal gjøre det godt i studiet.

Performance. Respondents’ achievement is measured by self-reported grade that they usually receive: “What is your typical grade at university?”. Response options ranged from A to F, which is a standardized grading system applied across Norwegian universities. Respondents are also asked to report their school grade average (1 = Lowest; 6 = Highest). 

Academic and social integration. The academic and intellectual development subscale from the Institutional Integration Scale is chosen as a measure of academic integration (Pascarella & Terenzini, 1980). Response alternatives were: 1 = Not true of me; 5 = Totally true of me. Original Cronbach’s Alpha (seven items) was .74. Three items from Peer-group interaction subscale are borrowed from the same measurement index (Pascarella & Terenzini, 1980). Original Cronbach’s Alpha (Seven Items) .84.


Items (Academic Integration; English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey): 

o	I am satisfied with the extent of my intellectual development since enrolling in this university / Jeg er fornøyd med hvor mye jeg har utviklet meg intellektuelt siden jeg startet på universitetet.
o	My academic experience has had a positive influence on my intellectual growth and interest in ideas / Mine akademiske erfaringer fra universitetet har hatt positiv innflytelse på min intellektuelle utvikling og faglige interesser.
o	My interest in ideas and intellectual matters has increased since coming to this university / Min interesse for ideer og intellektuelle spørsmål har økt siden jeg begynte på universitetet.

Items (Social Integration; English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey):
o	Since coming to this university I have developed close personal relationships with other students / Jeg har utviklet nære personlige relasjoner med andre medstudenter etter at jeg kom til dette universitetet.
o	The student friendships I have developed at this university have been personally satisfying / De vennskapene jeg har utviklet med andre medstudenter på dette universitetet har vært personlig tilfredsstillende.
o	It has been difficult for me to meet and make friends with other students / Det har vært vanskelig for meg å møte og bli venner med andre studenters

Drop-out intentions. Two items are taken from the study by Hardre and Reeve (2003): “I sometimes consider dropping out of university before graduation”, “I intend to drop out of school before graduation”. Original Cronbach’s Alpha (three items) .79. The third item was excluded due to complexity and unclear logic for inclusion in the original study (“I sometimes feel unsure about continuing my studies year after year”). Based on the Mindset theory of Action Phases (Gollwitzer, 1990), two additional items were designed for this study which intend to measure predesisional and preactional intentions.

Items (English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey):

o	I sometimes consider dropping out of university before graduation / Av og til vurderer jeg å slutte studiene før jeg er ferdig med planlagt studieløp (eksamen, grad).
o	I intend to drop out of university before graduation / Jeg kommer til å slutte å studere før jeg er ferdig med planlagt studieløp (eksamen, grad).
o	I sometimes think that other job opportunities suit me better than those I can get with my current education / Av og til tenker jeg at andre jobbmuligheter enn de studiene gir, passer bedre for meg.
o	I know what I am going to do if I withdraw from my studies / Jeg vet hva blir mitt neste steg hvis jeg avbryter studiene.

Transfer-out intentions. Two items are taken from the same study by Hardre and Reeve (2003) but rephrased with a focus on transfer-out intentions (e.g., consider changing university, intend to change university). Transfer-out intentions were divided into intentions to change university and study field and were asked separately. Similar to the drop-out intentions’ measure, two items were devised based on the Mindset Theory of Action Phases (Gollwitzer, 1990).

Items (University; English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey):

o	I sometimes consider changing university before graduation / Av og til vurderer jeg å slutte studiene før jeg er ferdig med planlagt studieløp (eksamen, grad).
o	I intend to change university before graduation / Jeg kommer til å slutte å studere før jeg er ferdig med planlagt studieløp (eksamen, grad).
o	I sometimes think about how my life would be if I change my studyplace/ Av og til tenker jeg at andre jobbmuligheter enn de studiene gir, passer bedre for meg.
o	I know what I am going to do if I withdraw from my studies / Jeg vet hva blir mitt neste steg hvis jeg avbryter studiene.

Items (Study Field; English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey):

o	I sometimes consider changing stuy field before graduation / Av og til vurderer jeg å endre studieretning før jeg er ferdig med planlagt studieløp (eksamen, grad).
o	I intend to change study field before graduation / Jeg kommer til å endre studieretning før jeg er ferdig med planlagt studieløp (eksamen, grad).
o	I sometimes think about advantages and disadvantages of changing study field/ Av og til vurderer jeg fordeler og ulemper ved å endre studieretning.
o	I am waiting for possibility to change my study field / Jeg venter på en mulighet for å endre studieretning.

Time-to-degree. The time students would spend on degree completion was a self-reported measure borrowed from Gillingham, Seneca, and Taussig (1991). Two questions are asked: “How long time have you spent studying at this program”, “How long do you expect it would take to finish your education”. Time-to-degree is a sum score of the time already spent in the program and self-reported expected remaining time. 

Procrastination. A subset of two items from the Academic Procrastination Scale (APS; Mccloskey & Scielzo, 2015; Yockey, 2016) will be used in the first part of the survey as an index of academic procrastination (e.g., When given an assignment, I usually put it away and forget about it until it is almost due”; “Cramming” and last minute studying is the best way that I study for a big test). Only two items were chosen due to the length of the questionnaire and served as an approximation of procrastination tendencies. Two items were chosen based on their high factor loadings. The items were translated to Norwegian with backward translations and discussion/correction (Kent Norby, unpublished). Cronbach alpha for 25 items is .94 (Mccloskey & Scielzo, 2015). In the second part of the questionnaire, the seven items from APS will be acquired. 

Items (English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey):

o	My attention span for schoolwork is very short / Mitt oppmerksomhetsspenn for skolearbeid er veldig kort.
o	I know I should work on school work, but I just don’t do it / Jeg vet jeg burde jobbe med skolearbeid, men jeg gjør det ikke.
o	I get distracted by other, more fun, things when I am supposed to work on schoolwork / Jeg blir distrahert av andre, mer morsomme ting, når jeg skulle jobbe med skolearbeid.
o	“Cramming” and last minute studying is the best way that I study for a big test / «Skippertak» og jobb i siste liten er måten jeg best forbereder meg til store prøver
o	When given an assignment, I usually put it away and forget about it until it is almost due / Når jeg får utdelt en oppgave, legger jeg den vanligvis til side helt til tidsfristen nesten er gått ut
o	Friends usually distract me from schoolwork / Venner distraherer meg vanligvis fra skolearbeid.
o	I don’t spend much time studying school material until the end of the semester / Jeg bruker ikke mye tid på å studere pensum før slutten av semesteret.


Our main outcome variables are students’ drop-out intentions, university transfer out intentions, study field transfer out intentions. Covariates included in the model: age, gender, parents’ education level, school performance, field of study, and transfer-out history (if a student have changed his field of study).  

Latent variables (factors) include: time-management skills, academic self-efficacy, academic integration, social integration, drop-out intentions, drop-out implementation intentions, university transfer out intentions, university transfer out implementation intentions, study field transfer out intentions, study field transfer out implementation intentions, and procrastination.
Time-to-degree: Sum of two items (see Variables section).

A full structural equation model (SEM) analysis will be employed to estimate a fit of the proposed model(s) (see Figure 1 and Figure 2). The difference between the Model 1 and Model 2 is the relationship between time-management skills, academic self-efficacy and attrition intentions. According to Bean and Eaton (2001), the variables predict students’ integration leading to intentions to persist or withdraw. Further, Elliot (2010) indicated that relationship between academic self-efficacy and social integration was insignificant. The opposite was found concerning the relationship between academic self-efficacy and academic integration. Thus, we expect that academic self-efficacy would not mediate the relationship between time-management skills and social integration. In sum, we aim to test two alternative models. The one depicted in the Figure one (Model 1) is expected to show a better fit compared to the one where academic self-efficacy mediates/ moderates the relationship between time-management skills and social integration.

Contrary, results of the meta-analysis by Robbins et al. (2004) indicate the direct “moderate” relationship between time-management skills, academic self-efficacy and retention. Since no previous studies have been found to investigate the relationship between these variables and types of attrition intentions, we aim to investigate if the relationship between time-management skills and attrition intentions would be mediated by self-efficacy (Model 2). Consequently, a set of alternative models would be tested. The main difference is the outcome variable (drop-out, transfer out intentions). The fit of the models would be compared to the fit of the models specifying indirect relationship between time-management skills, academic self-efficacy and attrition intentions (Model 1).

Alternatively, if the mediation/moderation effect of academic self-efficacy is not indicated, we would test the direct relationship between time-management skills, academic self-efficacy, and the described variables.  

The relationship between procrastination and attrition intentions is assumed to be mediated/ moderated by time-to-degree (Bair & Haworth, 2005: Muszynski & Akamatsu, 1991; Wadkins, 1999). Contrary, procrastination is commonly associated with poor academic performance, time-management skills and self-efficacy (Klingsieck et al., 2013; Steel, 2007). Thus, academic integration and students’ performance will be tested for potential mediation/ moderation effects. 

Model fit data will be examined using chi-square test, CFI, TLI, RMSEA, and SRMR. Standard fit cut-off values will be applied: CFI, TLI values greater than .95 (Hu & Bentler, 1999), SRMR less than .08 (Hu & Bentler, 1999), and RMSEA less than .05 (MacCallum, Browne, & Sugawara, 1996). Values equal to or lesser/higher than cut-off values indicate good and close fit. Analyses will be performed with STATA or Mplus software. The method of model estimation (e.g., maximum likelihood, weighted least squares) will be determined based on the properties of the data collected (e.g., multivariate normality). Pairwise and list-wise deletion will be applied to missing data. Abnormal responses, e.g., the same answers on all the questions, short completion time, will be excluded.

registration_responses.q1: Drop-out and transfer-out intentions. The role of academic and social integration
registration_responses.q2: Efim Nemtcan, Rannveig Grøm Sæle, Thor Gamst-Klaussen, Frode Svartdal
registration_responses.q3: Obtaining a higher education diploma has become an essential prerequisite for economic and social mobility, success, and well-being. However, attrition across European universities is high (Vossensteyn et al., 2015). According to Aamodt and Hovdhaugen (2011), attrition rates among investigated cohorts of Norwegian students are stable and vary around 20%. The issue represents a social (e.g., ineffective use of governmental funding, financial loss for state universities) as well as individual loss (e.g., time spent unemployed). Attrition is a multifaceted phenomenon and can vary depending on the reasons and observed consequences of the behavior, e.g., drop-out, transfer out, stop-out, opt-out (Hoyt & Winn, 2004). Few studies explicitly investigate differences in factors predicting these types of attrition. To our knowledge, only Hovdhaugen (2009) addressed this issue in the Norwegian context by comparing causes of drop-out and transfer out behaviors among university students. Consequently, a cross-cultural investigation of the phenomenon is required. Further, based on the Student Attrition Model by Bean (1982), and The Student Retention Integrated Model by Cabrera, Nora, and Castaneda (1993), students’ intentions are significant determinants of future behavior. The assumption is in accordance with the Theory of Reasoned Action (Fishbein & Ajzen, 1975) and the Theory of Planned Behavior (Ajzen, 1991). However, not every intention is realized (Bagozzi & Yi, 1989). The solution has been proposed by Gollwitzer (1990) in the Mindset Theory of Action Phases, implementation intentions. The available evidence facilitates validity of the notion (Bagozzi & Yi, 1989; Rise, Thompson, & Verplanken, 2003). In the current study, we aim to investigate if two Tinto’s (1975) most prominent constructs of academic and social integration would show the same pattern of relationship with drop-out and transfer out intentions/implementation intentions. The relationships between these two constructs and attrition intentions has been rarely investigated. Our second aim is to investigate the relationship between procrastination and students’ intentions. To our knowledge, only a single study by Grau and Minguillon (2013) addressed this issue.
registration_responses.q4:
See attached file for the graphic representation of hypothesises.

Hypothesis 1:

4.1.	Directional: Better academic and social integration would be related to higher/lower drop-out and transfer out intentions among students (e.g., Bean, 1982; Cabrera et al., 1993; Fishbein & Ajzen, 1975; Gollwitzer, 1990; Tinto, 1975).

4.2.	Directional: Higher academic performance would be related to attrition intentions (e.g., Bean & Metzner, 1985; Pascarella & Terenzini, 1980).

4.3.	Directional: Direct and indirect effect of time-management skills on attrition intentions would be mediated/moderated by students’ self-efficacy (Foerst, Klug, Jöstl, Spiel, & Schober, 2017).

 
o	Directional: Higher time-management skills and self-efficacy would be related to lower attrition intentions via higher academic integration, e.g., indirect effect (Tinto, 1975; Bean & Metzner, 1985).

o	Directional: Higher scores on time-management skills and self-efficacy could also be directly related to lower attrition intentions, e.g., direct effect (Ajzen, 1991; Gollwitzer, 1990; Robbins et al., 2004).

Hypothesis 2:

4.4.	Directional: More reported procrastination would be related to more attrition intentions and the relationship would be mediated/moderated by time-to-degree (Bair & Haworth, 2005; Klingsieck, Grund, Schmid, & Fries, 2013; Muszynski & Akamatsu, 1991; Wadkins, 1999).

4.5.	Directional: The relationship between procrastination and attrition intentions would be mediated/moderated by academic integration (Klingsieck et al., 2013; Tinto, 1975).

4.6.	Directional: The relationship between procrastination and attrition intentions would be mediated/moderated by performance (Klingsieck et al., 2013; Steel, 2007).

registration_responses.q13: Our target sample size is 641 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 700 accounting for attrition rates (10%). Our goal in testing Model 1 (Figure 1) is to obtain .95 power to detect low size (Cohen’s d) of .20 at the standard alpha error level = .05 (8 latent variables and 29 observed variables). We do not expect to obtain equally large sample for our second questionnaire. Thus, we aim to collect responses from at least 500 participants. The sample size is appropriate for obtaining .85 power level to detect low effect (d = .20) at the standard alpha level of .05. Soper’s (2019) a-priori sample size calculator for structural equation models was used to determine required sample size. No previous research that is similar to the current study was indicated. Consequently, our sample size estimation was based on evaluation of effects sizes reported between different sets of variables (e.g., Bean, 1982; Richardson, Abraham, & Bond, 2012; Robbins et al., 2004), time constrains, and feasibility.

registration_responses.q12.question:
Potential participant from different Norwegian institutions of higher education (e.g., UiO University of Oslo, UiB University of Bergen, NTNU Norwegian University of Science and Technology, UiT The Arctic University of Norway) will be invited to complete a short questionnaire (8-10 minutes). Students will be recruited through an e-mail (university’s mail addresses), social media (Facebook), and snowballing. 

Data collection has begun in November 2019 and will continue until the end of February (2020). The questionnaire is separated into two parts. The aim of splitting the questionnaire is to increase response rate and statistical power of the study (Galesic & Bosnjak, 2009). The first part is focused on students’ time-management skills, self-efficacy, integration and attrition intentions. Only two questions from Academic Procrastination Scale (APS) index are included. In the second part of the questionnaire, students will be asked to answer seven questions from APS. We aim to obtain a more valid indicator of students’ procrastination. Time-management skills and self-efficacy measures will be reduced to two measures based on CFA results of the first part of the study (e.g., highest loadings). All other measurement scales are similar to those used in the first part. Participants will be invited to participate in the lottery where they could win 1 out of 15 gift cards.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Time-management skills. The time management subscale from ASSIST inventory will be used to measure study-related skills (Diseth, 2007). The items were chosen based on their internal reliability (Cronbach’s Alpha .72; Diseth, 2001), possible data collection issues, and diversity of our sample (e.g., humanity, medicine, STEM students). Response options ranged from 1 = Totally agree to 5 = Totally disagree. A subset of two items will be used in the second part of the questionnaire based on highest loadings (results of the first questionnaire).

Items (English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey): 
o	I organise my study time carefully to make the best use of it / Jeg organiserer studietiden min nøye for å utnytte den best mulig.
o	I’m pretty good at getting down to work whenever I need to / Jeg er ganske flink å komme i gang med skolearbeidet når jeg trenger.
o	I work steadily through the term or semester, rather than leave it all until the last minute / Jeg jobber heller jevnt gjennom hele semesteret fremfor å la alt vente til siste liten
o	I generally make good use of my time during the day / Stort sett kan jeg bruke tiden godt gjennom arbeidsdagen.

Academic self-efficacy.  The measurement index is borrowed from a Danish study by Herrmann, Bager-Elsborg, and McCune (2017). Scale is based on MSLQ (Motivated Strategies for Learning Questionnaire) by Pintrich et al. (1991). Self-efficacy, as it is used here, refers to the students’ self-appraisal of their ability to master a task and includes judgment about their ability to accomplish a task as well as their confidence in their skills to perform that task (Pintrich et al. 1991). Three items were chosen based on the reported highest loadings (Hermann et al., 2017). Original Cronbach’s alpha (five items) was .83. A subset of two items will be used in the second part of the questionnaire based on highest loadings (results of the first questionnaire).

Items (English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey):: 

o	I am confident that I can acquire the skills necessary to excel within my field of study / Jeg er trygg på at jeg kan tilegne meg ferdighetene som er nødvendige for å utmerke meg innen mitt studiefelt.
o	I believe I will do well in my studies, as long as I make an effort / Jeg har tro på at jeg skal gjøre det bra i studiet, så lenge jeg gjør en innsats.
o	I expect to do well in my studies / Jeg forventer at jeg skal gjøre det godt i studiet.

Performance. Respondents’ achievement is measured by self-reported grade that they usually receive: “What is your typical grade at university?”. Response options ranged from A to F, which is a standardized grading system applied across Norwegian universities. Respondents are also asked to report their school grade average (1 = Lowest; 6 = Highest). 

Academic and social integration. The academic and intellectual development subscale from the Institutional Integration Scale is chosen as a measure of academic integration (Pascarella & Terenzini, 1980). Response alternatives were: 1 = Not true of me; 5 = Totally true of me. Original Cronbach’s Alpha (seven items) was .74. Three items from Peer-group interaction subscale are borrowed from the same measurement index (Pascarella & Terenzini, 1980). Original Cronbach’s Alpha (Seven Items) .84.


Items (Academic Integration; English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey): 

o	I am satisfied with the extent of my intellectual development since enrolling in this university / Jeg er fornøyd med hvor mye jeg har utviklet meg intellektuelt siden jeg startet på universitetet.
o	My academic experience has had a positive influence on my intellectual growth and interest in ideas / Mine akademiske erfaringer fra universitetet har hatt positiv innflytelse på min intellektuelle utvikling og faglige interesser.
o	My interest in ideas and intellectual matters has increased since coming to this university / Min interesse for ideer og intellektuelle spørsmål har økt siden jeg begynte på universitetet.

Items (Social Integration; English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey):
o	Since coming to this university I have developed close personal relationships with other students / Jeg har utviklet nære personlige relasjoner med andre medstudenter etter at jeg kom til dette universitetet.
o	The student friendships I have developed at this university have been personally satisfying / De vennskapene jeg har utviklet med andre medstudenter på dette universitetet har vært personlig tilfredsstillende.
o	It has been difficult for me to meet and make friends with other students / Det har vært vanskelig for meg å møte og bli venner med andre studenters

Drop-out intentions. Two items are taken from the study by Hardre and Reeve (2003): “I sometimes consider dropping out of university before graduation”, “I intend to drop out of school before graduation”. Original Cronbach’s Alpha (three items) .79. The third item was excluded due to complexity and unclear logic for inclusion in the original study (“I sometimes feel unsure about continuing my studies year after year”). Based on the Mindset theory of Action Phases (Gollwitzer, 1990), two additional items were designed for this study which intend to measure predesisional and preactional intentions.

Items (English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey):

o	I sometimes consider dropping out of university before graduation / Av og til vurderer jeg å slutte studiene før jeg er ferdig med planlagt studieløp (eksamen, grad).
o	I intend to drop out of university before graduation / Jeg kommer til å slutte å studere før jeg er ferdig med planlagt studieløp (eksamen, grad).
o	I sometimes think that other job opportunities suit me better than those I can get with my current education / Av og til tenker jeg at andre jobbmuligheter enn de studiene gir, passer bedre for meg.
o	I know what I am going to do if I withdraw from my studies / Jeg vet hva blir mitt neste steg hvis jeg avbryter studiene.

Transfer-out intentions. Two items are taken from the same study by Hardre and Reeve (2003) but rephrased with a focus on transfer-out intentions (e.g., consider changing university, intend to change university). Transfer-out intentions were divided into intentions to change university and study field and were asked separately. Similar to the drop-out intentions’ measure, two items were devised based on the Mindset Theory of Action Phases (Gollwitzer, 1990).

Items (University; English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey):

o	I sometimes consider changing university before graduation / Av og til vurderer jeg å slutte studiene før jeg er ferdig med planlagt studieløp (eksamen, grad).
o	I intend to change university before graduation / Jeg kommer til å slutte å studere før jeg er ferdig med planlagt studieløp (eksamen, grad).
o	I sometimes think about how my life would be if I change my studyplace/ Av og til tenker jeg at andre jobbmuligheter enn de studiene gir, passer bedre for meg.
o	I know what I am going to do if I withdraw from my studies / Jeg vet hva blir mitt neste steg hvis jeg avbryter studiene.

Items (Study Field; English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey):

o	I sometimes consider changing stuy field before graduation / Av og til vurderer jeg å endre studieretning før jeg er ferdig med planlagt studieløp (eksamen, grad).
o	I intend to change study field before graduation / Jeg kommer til å endre studieretning før jeg er ferdig med planlagt studieløp (eksamen, grad).
o	I sometimes think about advantages and disadvantages of changing study field/ Av og til vurderer jeg fordeler og ulemper ved å endre studieretning.
o	I am waiting for possibility to change my study field / Jeg venter på en mulighet for å endre studieretning.

Time-to-degree. The time students would spend on degree completion was a self-reported measure borrowed from Gillingham, Seneca, and Taussig (1991). Two questions are asked: “How long time have you spent studying at this program”, “How long do you expect it would take to finish your education”. Time-to-degree is a sum score of the time already spent in the program and self-reported expected remaining time. 

Procrastination. A subset of two items from the Academic Procrastination Scale (APS; Mccloskey & Scielzo, 2015; Yockey, 2016) will be used in the first part of the survey as an index of academic procrastination (e.g., When given an assignment, I usually put it away and forget about it until it is almost due”; “Cramming” and last minute studying is the best way that I study for a big test). Only two items were chosen due to the length of the questionnaire and served as an approximation of procrastination tendencies. Two items were chosen based on their high factor loadings. The items were translated to Norwegian with backward translations and discussion/correction (Kent Norby, unpublished). Cronbach alpha for 25 items is .94 (Mccloskey & Scielzo, 2015). In the second part of the questionnaire, the seven items from APS will be acquired. 

Items (English/ the Norwegian translation is used in the survey):

o	My attention span for schoolwork is very short / Mitt oppmerksomhetsspenn for skolearbeid er veldig kort.
o	I know I should work on school work, but I just don’t do it / Jeg vet jeg burde jobbe med skolearbeid, men jeg gjør det ikke.
o	I get distracted by other, more fun, things when I am supposed to work on schoolwork / Jeg blir distrahert av andre, mer morsomme ting, når jeg skulle jobbe med skolearbeid.
o	“Cramming” and last minute studying is the best way that I study for a big test / «Skippertak» og jobb i siste liten er måten jeg best forbereder meg til store prøver
o	When given an assignment, I usually put it away and forget about it until it is almost due / Når jeg får utdelt en oppgave, legger jeg den vanligvis til side helt til tidsfristen nesten er gått ut
o	Friends usually distract me from schoolwork / Venner distraherer meg vanligvis fra skolearbeid.
o	I don’t spend much time studying school material until the end of the semester / Jeg bruker ikke mye tid på å studere pensum før slutten av semesteret.


Our main outcome variables are students’ drop-out intentions, university transfer out intentions, study field transfer out intentions. Covariates included in the model: age, gender, parents’ education level, school performance, field of study, and transfer-out history (if a student have changed his field of study).  

Latent variables (factors) include: time-management skills, academic self-efficacy, academic integration, social integration, drop-out intentions, drop-out implementation intentions, university transfer out intentions, university transfer out implementation intentions, study field transfer out intentions, study field transfer out implementation intentions, and procrastination.

attributes.title: Bodily Maps of Moral Concerns
attributes.description: The somatosensory reaction to different social circumstances has been proposed to trigger conscious emotional experiences. Here, we present a pre-registered experiment in which we examine the topographical maps associated with violations of different moral concerns. Specifically, participants (N = 596) were randomly assigned to scenarios of moral violations, and then drew their subjective somatosensory experience on two 48,954-pixel silhouettes. We demonstrate that bodily representations of different moral violations are slightly different. Further, we demonstrate that violations of moral concerns are felt in different parts of the body, and arguably result in different somatosensory experiences for liberals and conservatives. We also investigate how individual differences in moral concerns relate to bodily maps of moral violations. Finally, we use natural language processing to predict activation in body parts based on the semantic representation of textual stimuli. The findings shed light on the complex relationships between moral violations and somatosensory experiences.

q1.value: Examining the Effect of Judgments of Cultural Appropriation and Appreciation on Intergroup Attitudes and Behaviors (Studies 3 & 4)

q3.value:
The second aim of the proposed research is to extend the examination of the effects of perceived cultural appropriation and cultural appreciation to intergroup attitudes and behaviors among dominant group members (White-Americans). 

Furthermore, racial biases can be unconscious and implicit, difficult to monitor and control, and are more likely to predict White’s nonverbal friendliness to Blacks in interracial interactions than explicit bias (Dovidio, Kawakami, & Gaertner, 2002). 

Therefore, Study 3 will focus on improving intergroup attitudes (implicit bias and willingness for intergroup contact), and Study 4 will focus on improving intergroup behaviors (nonverbal expressions of bias interaction) through mechanisms of out-group empathy and intergroup threat.

q4.value:
Study 3 Expected Results: Psychological Investment Increases Judgments of Appreciation: 
H1: Among participants who read about a White actor advertising culturally-Black hairstyles, those in the high (vs. low) investment condition will report greater perceptions of cultural appreciation. 
H2: Among participants who read about a White actor advertising culturally-Black hairstyles, those in the high (vs. low) investment condition will exhibit more positive intergroup attitudes (e.g. lower implicit bias, greater out-group empathy, reduced intergroup threat, greater willingness for intergroup contact).
H3: Among participants exposed to high intergroup trust, those who read about a White actor advertising culturally-Black hairstyles (vs. no out-group culture use) will exhibit more positive intergroup attitudes (e.g. greater out-group empathy, reduced intergroup threat, lower implicit bias, greater willingness for intergroup contact).
H4: Out-group empathy and reduced intergroup threat will mediate the interactive effect on implicit bias and willingness for intergroup contact. 
H5: The predicted effects described above will be stronger for participants who have had little to no contact with the source community (versus frequent contact). 

Study 4 Expected Results: Cultural Appreciation & Investment Improves Interracial Interactions
H1: Replicating the effects of Study 3, among participants who read about a White actor advertising culturally-Black hairstyles, those in the high (vs. low) intergroup trust condition will report greater perceptions of cultural appreciation.
H2: Among participants who read about a White actor advertising culturally-Black hairstyles, those in the high (versus low) intergroup trust condition will show less implicit race bias, express less explicit race bias on self-report measures (e.g. greater willingness for intergroup contact, and greater out-group empathy), and show lower expressions of discrimination (as coded by less eye contact, greater frequency of speech error, greater frequency in fidgeting, and displaying a more rigid body posture).
H3: Among participants exposed to high (vs. low) intergroup trust, those who read about cultural appreciation (vs. no out-group culture use) will show lower implicit bias and lower expressions of discrimination (as coded by less eye contact, greater frequency of speech error, greater frequency in fidgeting, and displaying a more rigid body posture).
H4: Out-group empathy and reduced intergroup threat will mediate the interactive effect on implicit bias and expressions of discrimination.  
H4: The predicted effects described above will be stronger for participants who have had little to no contact with the source community (versus frequent contact).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Both studies will use a 2 (Out Group Culture Use: Out-Group Culture Use vs. No Out-Group Culture Use) X 2 (Intergroup Trust: High vs. Low) between-subjects design. In this study, we were specifically interested in changing the racial attitudes of members of the dominant group (e.g. White-Americans) towards members of a minority source community (e.g. Black-Americans).

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to conditions via a randomizer embedded within the platform, Qualtrics (qualtrics.com).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Study 3 Procedures. After giving consent, participants will be asked to read and evaluate a magazine review about race-relations in America. This will manipulate the extent to which White-Americans can be highly trusted (high investment) or lowly trusted (low investment), adopting methods from previous research regarding intergroup trust (Dovidio et al, 2008; Noor et al., 2008): 
Intergroup Trust Manipulation. I will randomly assign participants to either the high intergroup trust condition or low intergroup trust condition. In the high intergroup trust condition, participants will read a news article titled “Improving Intergroup Trust in America” with the statistics that suggesting that the majority of White Americans (82%) agree with the following statement: “We should not forget the oppression and suffering of Black-Americans throughout the history of this country,” and 76% of White-Americans agree that “they are psychologically invested in the issues the plight the Black community.” The article will discuss how the majority of White Americans value cooperative solutions to race related problems, and are working hard for peaceful race relations. In the low intergroup trust condition, participants will read a news article titled “Waning Intergroup Trust in America” with the statistics that suggest only 30% of White Americans agree with the statement “We should not forget the oppression and suffering of Black-Americans throughout the history of this country.” The article will discuss how the majority of White Americans are not working hard enough on finding cooperative solutions to race-related problems. Participants will read a second, ostensibly unrelated magazine article, which will discuss the details of an up and coming hair salon, as well as information about the owner. The information will be consistent throughout the conditions, except for the manipulation of out-group culture use:
Out Group Culture Use Manipulation. I will randomly assign participants to either the out-group culture use condition, or the no out-group culture use condition. In the out-group culture use condition, participants will read about a White-American hairstylist/salon owner advertising Black-American hairstyles (e.g. Dreadlocked Hair Weaves) on White models. In the no out-group culture use condition, participants will read about a White-American hairstylist/salon owner advertising White-American hairstyles (e.g. Blonde Straight Hair Extensions) on White models. This procedure is adapted from previous research manipulating out-group culture use via hairstyle (Studies 1-4; Mosley & Biernat, accepted pending revision, Journal of Personality and Social Psychology).
Manipulation check of out-group culture use.  Pilot data was collected using a sample of Mturk participants (N = 60) to test the effectiveness of the out-group culture manipulation. Preliminary results revealed that participants were more likely to categorize White-American hairstyles (e.g., Blonde Straight Hair Extensions) as “attributed to White (vs. Black)-American culture),” and more likely to categorize the Black-American hairstyles e.g. Dreadlocked Hair Weaves as “attributed to Black (vs. White)-American culture” (ps <.05). This preliminary finding demonstrates a successful manipulation of out-group culture use designed for the proposed studies.
Manipulation check of psychological investment. Pilot data was collected using a sample of Mturk participants (N = 60) to test the effectiveness of the psychological investment manipulation. Preliminary results revealed that participants in the high intergroup condition reported that White-Americans “care more,” are more empathetic towards issues of the Black community” than those in the low intergroup trust condition (p < .05). This preliminary finding demonstrates a successful, but varied, manipulation of psychological investment designed for the proposed studies. 
Participants then will complete dependent measures:
Dependent Measures: Participants will complete the same measures of perceptions of cultural appropriation and perceptions of cultural appreciation as in Study 1 (1= Strongly Disagree, 7 = Strongly Agree). Intergroup attitudes will be assessed using measures of a) implicit race bias, b) out-group empathy, c) intergroup threat, and d) willingness for intergroup contact. To assess participants implicit race bias, participants will first be asked to complete the race implicit association test (IAT), which assesses the speed of positive and negative associations between racial categories (Black and White) (Greenwald et al., 1998). Participants will also indicate their agreement with the following self-report measures (1= Strongly Disagree, 7 = Strongly Agree): out-group empathy, (adapted from Noor et al., 2008; 6 items: “When I think about Black -Americans, I feel empathy/ compassion/ sympathy/ understanding”), intergroup threat (Stephan & Stephan, 2013; 12 items: “I feel anxious when I think about Black-Americans”), and willingness for future intergroup contact (Esses & Dovidio, 2000; 11 items, e.g., “How willing would you be to engage in the following behaviors if given the opportunity: confide in a Black person?”). To assess moderation, will also complete the same measure of intergroup contact as in Studies 1 and 2. Participants will complete demographics and will be fully debriefed. 

Study 4 Procedures. As a cover story, participants will be told that we will be studying the effects of reading comprehension on social interactions. Participants be told that they will interact with a student in a different room, but will first read a brief article to assess their reading comprehension abilities. After giving consent, participants will be asked to read and evaluate a magazine review of a local hair salon. The magazine review will discuss the details of an up and coming hair salon, as well as information about the owner. The information in the magazine review will be consistent throughout the conditions, except for the manipulations of out-group culture use and psychological investment: 
Out-Group Culture Use Manipulation. As in Study 3. the magazine review will manipulate the extent to which that target is engaged in the use of an out-group cultural product (out-group culture use condition vs. the no out-group culture use condition) using the same procedures. 
Intergroup Trust Manipulation. In addition, the magazine review will manipulate the extent to which there is a sense of high (vs. low) intergroup trust between the in-group (White-Americans) and the out-group (Black-Americans), using the manipulation in Study 3. Participants will complete measures:
Dependent Measures:  Using the same measures in Study 3, we will assess participants’ perceptions of cultural appropriation and appreciation, out-group empathy, intergroup threat, willingness for future intergroup contact, implicit biases, and their past intergroup contact, After completing these measures, participants will be escorted to a different room by the experimenter. In this room, there will be two chairs, and sitting in the chair, there will be a confederate of Black-American ethnicity playing the role of a student with a video camera in the middle of the room. Participants will then be asked to engage in an interaction with a gender-matched ostensible student (actually a confederate of the lab). Four confederates will be trained to engage in a structured discussion (2 males, 2 females). For generalizability, multiple confederates will be used to be sure that score differences are specifically due to race, and not to idiosyncratic confederate effects. The participant and the confederate will be instructed to have a brief three-minute interaction where they introduce themselves, discuss their backgrounds, majors, and any other information about themselves they would like to share. The procedures of this interaction will be adapted from previous research examining expressions of discrimination (Dovidio, Kawakami, Johnson, Johnson & Howard,1997; Goff, Steele, & Davies, 2008). Interactions will be videotaped to allow for future coding of nonverbal expressions of discrimination throughout the interaction. Four trained research assistants will later code the videos for nonverbal indicators of intergroup bias (Dovidio, et al.,1997; Goff, Steele, & Davies, 2008): including less time spent engaging in eye contact (in seconds), greater frequency of speech error (number of times the participant stumbles on their words), greater frequency in fidgeting (how many times the participant displays an uncomfortable use of the hands), and displaying a rigid body posture (0-leaned back, 1 – supine position, 2 – leaned forward in interest). Participants will complete demographic measures and will be debriefed.

q14.value: A power analysis using G*power was conducted assuming a medium effect size (ΔR2 = .05), α = .05, and 85% power in a 2 x 2 ANOVA model.

registration_responses.q1: Examining the Effect of Judgments of Cultural Appropriation and Appreciation on Intergroup Attitudes and Behaviors (Studies 3 & 4)
registration_responses.q3:
The second aim of the proposed research is to extend the examination of the effects of perceived cultural appropriation and cultural appreciation to intergroup attitudes and behaviors among dominant group members (White-Americans). 

Furthermore, racial biases can be unconscious and implicit, difficult to monitor and control, and are more likely to predict White’s nonverbal friendliness to Blacks in interracial interactions than explicit bias (Dovidio, Kawakami, & Gaertner, 2002). 

Therefore, Study 3 will focus on improving intergroup attitudes (implicit bias and willingness for intergroup contact), and Study 4 will focus on improving intergroup behaviors (nonverbal expressions of bias interaction) through mechanisms of out-group empathy and intergroup threat.
registration_responses.q4:
Study 3 Expected Results: Psychological Investment Increases Judgments of Appreciation: 
H1: Among participants who read about a White actor advertising culturally-Black hairstyles, those in the high (vs. low) investment condition will report greater perceptions of cultural appreciation. 
H2: Among participants who read about a White actor advertising culturally-Black hairstyles, those in the high (vs. low) investment condition will exhibit more positive intergroup attitudes (e.g. lower implicit bias, greater out-group empathy, reduced intergroup threat, greater willingness for intergroup contact).
H3: Among participants exposed to high intergroup trust, those who read about a White actor advertising culturally-Black hairstyles (vs. no out-group culture use) will exhibit more positive intergroup attitudes (e.g. greater out-group empathy, reduced intergroup threat, lower implicit bias, greater willingness for intergroup contact).
H4: Out-group empathy and reduced intergroup threat will mediate the interactive effect on implicit bias and willingness for intergroup contact. 
H5: The predicted effects described above will be stronger for participants who have had little to no contact with the source community (versus frequent contact). 

Study 4 Expected Results: Cultural Appreciation & Investment Improves Interracial Interactions
H1: Replicating the effects of Study 3, among participants who read about a White actor advertising culturally-Black hairstyles, those in the high (vs. low) intergroup trust condition will report greater perceptions of cultural appreciation.
H2: Among participants who read about a White actor advertising culturally-Black hairstyles, those in the high (versus low) intergroup trust condition will show less implicit race bias, express less explicit race bias on self-report measures (e.g. greater willingness for intergroup contact, and greater out-group empathy), and show lower expressions of discrimination (as coded by less eye contact, greater frequency of speech error, greater frequency in fidgeting, and displaying a more rigid body posture).
H3: Among participants exposed to high (vs. low) intergroup trust, those who read about cultural appreciation (vs. no out-group culture use) will show lower implicit bias and lower expressions of discrimination (as coded by less eye contact, greater frequency of speech error, greater frequency in fidgeting, and displaying a more rigid body posture).
H4: Out-group empathy and reduced intergroup threat will mediate the interactive effect on implicit bias and expressions of discrimination.  
H4: The predicted effects described above will be stronger for participants who have had little to no contact with the source community (versus frequent contact).

attributes.title: Need Thwarting and Dissatisfaction as it Relates to Perfectionism

q1.value: Need Thwarting and Dissatisfaction as it Relates to Perfectionism Experiment 2

q3.value: Replicate and extend the findings of the previous experiment. See collaborators 'Projects' for further detail and review of the literature.

q4.value:
H1: Those in the competence frustration condition will show higher levels of black and white thinking as compared to those in the competence satisfaction and control conditions. 

H2: Those in the competence satisfaction group will show no increase in levels of black and white thinking as compared to those in the control condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is a between subjects design with 3 levels (control, need frustration, & need satisfaction)

q9.value: Randomization of participants will occur, assigning participants to 1 of 3 blocks. This is done automatically using the "Randomizer" feature in Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: This study will use convenience sampling of participants recruited through Prolific software. Participants will be offered remuneration for their participation which will be determined by the current hourly wage at the time of the study. Exclusionary criteria for vulnerable populations will be enforced and participants will first be screened with a subset of qualifier questions to dismiss any vulnerable populations. Participants will be over the age of 18 and the sample will be limited to those whose primary language is English. Prolific allows researchers to have access to a large population of willing participants for research studies. Participants will have free choice of what studies they participate in and the sample varies widely in age, race, and other demographic information. Participants will receive $3.50 for participation (an average of $8/hour).

q13.value: A minimum of 300 participants will be recruited

q14.value: Participant amount will be determined using a power analysis.

question.value: We manipulated basic needs by either threatening or satisfying competence. Additionally, a control condition existed.

We will be measuring perfectionism using the Measure of Constructs Underlying Perfectionism (MCUP), basic needs using the Basic Needs Satisfaction and Frustration Scale, need for closure using the Need For Closure (NFC) scale, and regulatory focus using the General Measure of Regulatory Focus.
Indices will be created based on mean of all items on a given scale.

The data analysis will consist of linear regression and mediation analyses. We will use need satisfaction/frustration and need for closure as predictors of the various subscales of perfectionism. We will use the procedures described by Hayes (2018) to test for mediation. We will also test for mean differences between the competence frustration/satisfaction conditions on need for closure and prevention/promotion focus using contrast coding in a linear regression analysis. We will follow the guidelines recommended by Cohen, Cohen, West, and Aiken (2003) to test for mean differences.

q20.value: Contrast coding (Helmert codes) will be used to test for mean differences in a linear regression analysis.

q22.value: Data exclusion will be based on participants who do not follow the conditions that must be met for the writing task assigned to them. Responses that are incoherent or off topic will be excluded from data analyses as determined two independent coders. Participants who fail to do so will be excluded. Additionally, participants who answer less than 50% of the questions on any survey will be excluded.

q23.value: Composite measures will be created by computing the mean of all the items for each scale. Listwise deletion will be used in cases if participants do not answer enough items for a score on any given measure.

We will use need satisfaction/frustration and need for closure as predictors of the various subscales of perfectionism. We will use the procedures described by Hayes (2018) to test for mediation. We will also test for mean differences between the competence frustration/satisfaction conditions on need for closure and prevention/promotion focus using contrast coding in a linear regression analysis. We will follow the guidelines recommended by Cohen, Cohen, West, and Aiken (2003) to test for mean differences.
